scenario:
Coca-Cola (KO) and Procter & Gamble (PG) are Dividend Kings with a history of raising their dividends for at least 50 consecutive years. Both companies have a consistent schedule for making these raises, with Coke announcing its raises in February or March and P&G in April. 

Coke has paid and raised its dividend for 62 consecutive years, with the last raise being a minimum of $0.01 per share per quarter. The company has a 3.1% yield and a 21.8 forward price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio. Coke has a history of acquisitions, expanding its business beyond soft drinks, and has compounded Topo Chico volumes by tenfold from pre-acquisition levels in 2016.

P&G has raised its dividend for 68 consecutive years, with the last raise being 7%. The company has a 2.4% yield and a 24.1 forward P/E ratio. P&G consistently repurchases a significant amount of stock, with a combined $146.49 billion spent on dividends and buybacks over the last decade. This has reduced its share count by 12.8% and artificially increased earnings per share (EPS).

Both companies have recession-resistant business models, selling relatively low-cost, daily use products that are less dependent on the economic cycle. They have a history of enduring market dynamics and raising their dividends no matter what the business cycle is doing.
